Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 45123-001  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
August 2011 
 
 
 
Regional Program for Research and  
Capacity Development on Water Security 
(Financed by the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation 
and Poverty Reduction Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  APWF  –  Asia-Pacific Water Forum 
  AWDO  –  Asian Water Development Outlook 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EARD  –  East Asia Department 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  WFP  –  Water Financing Program 
  WOP  –  water operational plan 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention  
Sector   –  Agriculture  and  natural  resources;  water  supply  and  other 
municipal infrastructure and services 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Environmental  sustainability  (eco-efficiency),  regional 
cooperation  and  integration,  governance,  capacity  development 
(client relations, network, and partnership development)  
Climate change  –  Climate change adaptation 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (medium), urban (medium), national (high), regional (high)

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.  
 
Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development  
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Director  G. H. Kim, Sustainable Infrastructure Division, RSDD  
    
Team leader  W. Lincklaen Arriens, Lead Water Resources Specialist, RSDD  
Team members  J. Liang, Principal Country Economist, East Asia Department 
  T. Esteban, Water Resources Officer, RSDD  
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB), guided by its Water for All policy,1 has been 
increasing its water investments in the region through its Water Financing Program (WFP), 
supported  by  the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility.  The  WFP  has  been  helping  ADB 
member countries in Asia and the Pacific to develop and implement innovative solutions that will 
increase water security through investments in rural and urban water services and integrated 
water resources management in river basins. Building on the results of its water operations from 
2001 to 2010, ADB is preparing a water operational plan (WOP) for 2011–2020. A priority of the 
WOP will be supporting ADB clients in addressing the water-food-energy security nexus in the 
region, so they can deal better with the impact of climate change. 
 
2.  In 2006, ADB commissioned the first Asian Water Development Outlook (AWDO) in 
collaboration with the Asia-Pacific Water Forum (APWF). The AWDO was launched to inform 
leaders at the First Asia-Pacific Water Summit in 2007 about the need to improve water security 
through governance. Following the successful reception of the first AWDO, ADB and the APWF 
formed a team of experts from regional water organization and knowledge hubs to prepare a 
second version, with guidance from advisers in the region, including from Peking University. 
 
3.  The AWDO team’s guiding vision for water security states that 
 
societies can enjoy water security when they successfully manage their water resources 
and services to: (i) satisfy household water and sanitation needs in all communities; 
(ii) support productive economies in agriculture and industry; (iii) develop vibrant, livable 
cities  and  towns;  (iv) restore  healthy  rivers  and  ecosystems;  and  (v) build  resilient 
communities that can adapt to change. 
 
These  five  dimensions  of  water  security  depend  on  investments  combined  with  better 
knowledge and governance. With improved water security, the region can reduce poverty, 
prosper, grow more sustainably, and be more resilient in the face of climate change. 
 
4.  To promote regional research and capacity development in water security, ADB reached 
an  understanding  with  the  Ministry  of  Finance  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC), 
Tsinghua University, and Peking University for the establishment and funding of a full-time 
Regional Research and Capacity Development Program on Water Security. In March 2011, 
Tsinghua University and Peking University set up the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security in 
Beijing to manage the program together with ADB. The program affirms ADB’s commitment to 
regional cooperation by giving priority to knowledge sharing and mutual learning in key sectors. 
Collaboration with the PRC’s centers of excellence is an important part of this commitment and 
marks  a  new  partnership  between  ADB  and  the  PRC  in  knowledge  sharing  for  regional 
cooperation  and  integration.  The  proposed  research  and  capacity  development  technical 
assistance (TA) will support the start of program implementation; it received concept clearance 
from ADB Management in March 2011. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
                                                 
1   ADB. 2001. Water for All: The Water Policy of the Asian Development Bank. Manila.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 May 2011.

2  
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Water security, along with food and energy security, is a fundamental need in Asia and 
the Pacific, where water is increasingly scarce, pollution is rife, and extreme events could cause 
more widespread disasters. Governments trying to deal with these challenges are significantly 
constrained by a lack of reliable data, comprehensive analysis, and effective solutions. In most 
countries, insufficient capacity, leadership, and regional cooperation keep decision makers from 
making the right investments and pursuing reforms to increase water security. 
 
6.  The program offers countries in the region a unique, first-time opportunity to pool their 
efforts and thereby achieve better results. It will be implemented through a partnership between  
ADB and the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security, and it will support collaboration with the 
center’s partner research institutes and capacity development centers, in Asia and the Pacific 
and elsewhere. 
 
7.  With support from the program, the center and its partners will conduct research to 
measure water security in the region and organize activities to develop the capacity to increase 
water security. Program activities will benefit from strategic direction from ADB (through its 
Water for All Policy and WOP) and the APWF. The approach to increasing water security will be 
comprehensive:  key  dimensions  (household,  economic,  urban,  environmental,  risks,  and 
resilience)  and  crosscutting  perspectives  (poverty  reduction,  governance,  food  and  energy 
security, green growth, and regional cooperation) will be covered. 
 
8.  The program will also enable the center to join forces with partner institutes and centers 
in the region and to facilitate the creation and functioning of an international team that will 
update future editions of the AWDO. This joint effort will build on the earlier part-time research 
work by ADB and knowledge partner organizations of the APWF that produced the first edition 
of  the  AWDO  in  2007  and  the  second  edition,  which  is  being  finalized  for  the  Second 
Asia-Pacific Water Summit in Bangkok in February 2012.  
 
9.  The program will form an important part of the knowledge platform that ADB is building 
with the PRC, and support regional cooperation among ADB’s developing member countries 
(DMCs) as part of the WFP 2011–2020. Regional cooperation is a cornerstone of ADB’s Water 
for All Policy, and an area where ADB will intensify its activities under the WOP’s guidance. The 
program  is  also  consistent  with  the  recent  focus  of  the  international  community 
(World Economic Forum, United Nations, and others) on water security and its links with food 
and energy security in the context of efforts to adapt to climate change. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The intended impact of the TA will be increased water security in Asia and the Pacific as 
expressed in the guiding vision of increasing household, economic, urban, and environmental 
water security, together with resilience and improved governance. Indexes for measuring water 
security in these key dimensions are being finalized for publication in the second edition of the 
AWDO and will be improved further with support from the program.

3
11.  The outcome of the TA (the first in a series of expected contributions in support of the 
program) will be a well-established institutional capacity for water security research and capacity 
development at the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security, working closely with its partner 
centers of excellence in and outside Asia and the Pacific. ADB will guide the achievement of this 
outcome, so that its DMCs can invest appropriately and institute reforms to increase water 
security,  helped  along  by  better  data  and  information,  comprehensive  analysis,  adequate 
institutional capacity, and regional cooperation. With ADB’s guidance, the center will develop a 
medium-term strategy for the program and the center, with emphasis on regional knowledge 
sharing. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  program  will  have  five  components.  It  will  (i)  gather,  analyze,  and  publish 
information about strategic water security issues and developments in the region, in the AWDO 
and  other  publications,  e-newsletters,  social  networking  and  other  websites,  and  a 
peer-reviewed journal; (ii) conduct research on water and related security issues in the region, 
with partners; (iii) foster leadership in capacity development, including education and training; 
(iv) strengthen collaborative partnerships with centers of excellence in and outside the region; 
and (v) promote knowledge sharing through  conferences, workshops, dialogues, study visits, 
internships,  fellowships,  and  other  forms  of  regional  cooperation.  The  TA  will  support  the 
program’s start-up activities, with the following expected output. 
 
13.  Information  output.  The  Asia-Pacific  Center  for  Water  Security  will  facilitate  the 
formation and operation of an international team for the program with partner institutions in the 
region, to conduct further research on water security in preparation for the third edition of the 
AWDO. Websites will be established for the center and the program to disseminate information 
in the region and beyond. Consultations will start on the development of a peer-reviewed journal 
on water security in Asia and the Pacific, to be implemented after the TA. 
 
14.  Research output. A framework for further research on water security will be developed 
to support a third edition of the AWDO with improved indicators for measuring water security. A 
database of water security–related information and indicators will be designed in partnership 
with ADB and with centers of excellence in and outside the region, including national research 
centers in ADB’s DMCs, and in the context of ADB’s intention to establish an Asian water 
information system or service. The results of the pilot application of AWDO’s water security 
indexes in selected river basins through the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations will be 
reported. A collaboration framework between the center and ADB will show how research in 
ADB-funded investment projects of the WFP can contribute to the program. 
 
15.  Leadership  output.  The  Asia-Pacific  Center  for  Water  Security  will  organize  an 
international workshop on Asia’s water-food-energy security nexus and make recommendations 
to leaders at the Second Asia-Pacific Water Summit in February 2012. The workshop will mark 
the launch of the center and the program. 
 
16.  Partnership output. The center will conduct a series of consultation visits to potential 
partner institutions in research and capacity development in and outside the region, including 
national research centers in DMCs, starting in Southeast Asia. These consultation visits are 
expected to result in memorandums of understanding for collaboration between the center and 
its partners. A framework for further research on water security will also be developed to support 
a third edition of the AWDO with improved indicators for measuring water security.

4  
17.  Knowledge-sharing  output.  The  center  will  provide  opportunities  for  research 
associates  from  DMCs  in  the  international  program  team  to  receive  on-the-job  training. 
Exchange programs with partner organizations will be explored as part of the memorandums of 
understanding (para. 16). The center will explore synergies with ADB’s country water sector 
assessments, ADB’s planned Future of Water in Asia study, and the Asia-Pacific Water Forum’s 
knowledge hubs initiative. An awards program will be designed to stimulate and recognize 
excellence among researchers, practitioners, and leaders in water security in the region. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund, to 
be  administered  by  ADB.  The  Asia-Pacific  Center  for  Water  Security  and  its  partners  are 
expected  to  make  additional  in-kind  contributions,  for  staff  input,  knowledge  products, 
information and data, and facilities, among others. Details of the cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB  will  execute  the  TA  through  its  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department, in cooperation with its East Asia Department (EARD) and the Water Community of 
Practice, and implement it through a partnership with the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security. 
EARD, through ADB’s PRC Resident Mission, will have a key role in TA implementation since 
the program will make an important contribution to the knowledge platform that ADB and the 
PRC are building.  ADB will execute letters of agreement and advance payment facilities with 
the center for the implementation of several activities, including the center’s consultation visits to 
Asian countries, the international workshop, and on-the-job training for research associates. 
ADB will also advise the center in the development of its medium-term strategy for the program.  
 
20.  TA implementation will involve the Water Community of Practice and ADB’s operations, 
starting with EARD and the Southeast Asia Department, and will be designed in a manner that 
allows ADB clients and staff to contribute to the activities of the program and benefit in practical 
ways from the results. For example, the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security and ADB will 
explore how projects of ADB’s WFP 2011–2020 can become case studies in water security 
research, how knowledge can be shared among projects, and how the knowledge products that 
are produced can be applied in ADB-supported projects. 
 
21.  Most of the TA resources are allocated to travel-related costs that enable experts to 
meet and work together in a variety of ways in the program. The Asia-Pacific Center for Water 
Security and its partners are expected to provide almost all the expert services through in-kind 
contributions, rather than through the TA budget for consulting services. For the day-to-day 
management of the program, the TA will require about 24 person-months of national (individual) 
consulting  services,  including  those  of  a  program  communications  manager  at  the  center 
(individual, full-time) and a water security research analyst at ADB (individual, full-time). In 
addition,  the  TA  may  require  about  2 person-months  (individual,  intermittent)  of  services 
provided by international resource persons with expertise in water, food, and energy security. 
The consultants will be hired in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. ADB staff will also participate in the TA as speakers and resource persons in the 
international workshop on water security, and as advisers to the Asia-Pacific Center for Water

5
Security. The TA disbursements will conform to ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
22.  The implementation of the TA will be monitored by ADB through regular consultations 
with the Asia-Pacific Center for Water Security and its partners. The TA output, good practices, 
and  lessons  learned  will  be  disseminated  through  ADB’s  and  the  center’s  websites,  and 
presented at regional forums and the Second Asia-Pacific Water Summit. 
 
23.  During the TA, the center and ADB will pursue supplementary funding from the People’s 
Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund  as  well  as 
complementary funding from other sources, including in-kind contributions from collaborating 
partner organizations in and outside the region.  
 
24.  The TA is expected to run for 15 months, from August 2011 to October 2012. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund for the Regional Program for Research and Capacity Development on Water Security, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

10        Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  International Resource Persons (2 person-months, individual, intermittent) 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of international resource persons 
to make presentations or facilitate discussions during the international workshop and training 
organized for this TA. These persons will have recognized expertise in water, food, and energy 
security, and in other topics related to the TA. The resource persons can come from the public 
or private sector, and from international or regional organizations. 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Program Communication Manager (12 person-months, individual, full-time) 
2.  The program communication manager will work at the Asia-Pacific Center for Water 
Security and be responsible for: 
(i)  developing  and  maintaining  the  website  for  the  center  and  the  Regional 
Research and Capacity Development Program, 
(ii)  coordinating arrangements for the consultation visits with prospective partner 
organizations, 
(iii)  coordinating preparations for the international workshop, 
(iv)  making arrangements for the on-the-job training program and further training and 
exchange activities under the program, 
(v)  preparing regular reports on the progress of work of the center and program, 
(vi)  supporting data compilation by the center’s team of experts, 
(vii)  communicating on day-to-day matters with the center’s clients and partners, and 
(viii)  performing related tasks assigned by the center and ADB. 
2.  Water Security Research Analyst (12 person-months, individual, full-time) 
3.  The  water  security  research  analyst  will  work  at  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and be responsible for: 
(i)  providing coordination and technical support for the preparation of the Asian 
Water Development Outlook, 
(ii)  researching sources of data and knowledge on water security, 
(iii)  making arrangements for linking the program with case studies in ADB-financed 
projects, 
(iv)  linking information on the program to ADB’s website, 
(v)  assisting in the organization of knowledge events at the Second Asia-Pacific 
Water Summit, 
(vi)  supporting activities of the Asia-Pacific Water Forum and knowledge hubs, and 
(vii)  performing related tasks assigned by the center and ADB. 
 
4.  The TA may require additional expertise, identified during inception. In that case, a 
change in scope will be made, as needed, to allow the hiring of the consultants.
